item.title: El gobierno de Trump actúa con rapidez para reestructurar su programa de aranceles
item.description: La nueva estrategia requerirá una serie de aranceles más engorrosos, que Trump no podrá imponer rápidamente ni por capricho.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: Word of the Day: glimpse
item.description: This word has appeared in 1,347 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: La generación del ‘doomscrolling’ tiene una banda sonora: el phonk
item.description: Los Shorts de YouTube y los videos de TikTok suelen estar acompañados de una música electrónica con raíces de rap que se ha convertido en el pulso sonoro del video vertical y enriquecido increíblemente a sus creadores.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Prada Bianchi

item.title: Kyiv Is Freezing, but There Is Warmth, Too
item.description: Delegations from Ukraine, Russia and the United States have been meeting in Abu Dhabi for peace talks. I hear it’s warm there.
item.dc:creator: Jenya Polosina and Anna Ivanenko

item.title: 4 años de la invasión a Ucrania: el respaldo de Europa se resquebraja
item.description: Hungría dijo que bloquearía tanto el más reciente paquete de sanciones contra Rusia como un paquete de ayuda financiera a Kiev por valor de alrededor de 106.000 millones de dólares.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Constant Méheut

media:content.media:credit: Mauricio Lima para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Agentes de policía en el lugar de una explosión en Leópolis, Ucrania, el domingo.

item.title: These Ukrainians Don’t Want to Be Traded to Russia for Peace
item.description: Four years into the war, a major sticking point in talks is control of the eastern Donetsk region. Residents could face an agonizing choice if Ukraine gives up the territory.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Lynsey Addario and Tyler Hicks

media:content.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Daria Bondareva last month with a customer at her salon in Sloviansk, Ukraine, in the Donetsk region.

item.title: After Six Decades of the War on Drugs, What Works?
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have spilled blood and treasure to kill drug lords and defeat cartels, but the drugs keep coming and the new groups are more violent than ever.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib

media:content.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara following the capture and killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: What Brontë Country Tells Us About Britain Today
item.description: West Yorkshire, where the original “Wuthering Heights” was written, offers a window into the forces that are disrupting British politics.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Andrew Testa

media:content.media:description: The windswept area of northern England where Emily Brontë wrote “Wuthering Heights” remains a place of startling natural beauty.

item.title: How Russia Put Its Future at Risk by Remaking Its Economy for War
item.description: About half of the country’s federal budget goes toward the fight in Ukraine, money that does little to support its long-term development.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne

media:content.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Russian troops during a rehearsal of the Victory Day military parade in Moscow, last year.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Young Man in a Hurry,’ by Gavin Newsom
item.description: The new book by the California governor and undeclared presidential hopeful depicts a man shaped as much by hardship and struggle as privilege.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Young Man in a Hurry: A Memoir of Discovery (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gavin Newsom, then mayor of San Francisco, introduces Hillary Clinton, then a presidential candidate, seen here with the actors Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, at a local fund-raiser in 2008.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 24, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 24, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Judges Lose Patience on Immigration Defiance
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 24, 2026.

item.title: Pentagon Races to Spend $153 Billion in Added Funds for Military
item.description: The Trump administration for months ignored Congress’s demand for a plan on how the Defense Department would spend the money that Republicans pushed through in their sweeping domestic policy bill.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Defense Department report to Congress detailed a range of priorities for extra funding, including purchasing over a dozen new ships, enhancing weapons manufacturing and integrating artificial intelligence into the military’s capabilities.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers: February 24, 2026
item.description: Adam Aaronson’s Tuesday puzzle serenades us.
item.dc:creator: Natan Last

media:content.media:credit: Erik Jacobs for The New York Times

item.title: La novia de ‘El Mencho’ fue clave en rastrear al líder del cártel, según las autoridades
item.description: Altos mandos de seguridad revelaron detalles de la operación que condujo a la muerte del líder del cártel de la droga más buscado de México.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: El general Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, secretario de Defensa de México, describió la operación de este fin de semana contra un alto dirigente de un cártel en una conferencia de prensa celebrada el lunes en Ciudad de México con la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: Qué debes saber si viajas a México tras la violencia por los cárteles
item.description: La muerte de un líder de un cártel y los disturbios posteriores han provocado cancelaciones de vuelos, bloqueos de carreteras, interrupciones de cruceros y alertas de buscar “refugio”.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner

media:content.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: El caos provocado por la muerte de Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, quien dirigía un poderoso grupo criminal, interrumpió los vuelos en el Aeropuerto Internacional de Guadalajara el domingo.

item.title: In Blow to Mamdani, Left-Leaning Group Breaks With Mayor Over U.S. House Race
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York had lobbied for his preferred candidate, Claire Valdez. But the party backed Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president, has been endorsed by Representative Nydia M. Velázquez, whom he is running to succeed in Congress.

item.title: ‘Mother Russia’ Review: A New Play That’s as Funny as It’s Smart
item.description: A strong cast stars in Lauren Yee’s new play, part of a cycle of works about the collisions between 20th-century communism and pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

media:content.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Steven Boyer as Dmitri and Adam Chanler-Berat as Evgeny getting a taste of capitalism in Lauren Yee’s “Mother Russia” at the Signature Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Queens Man Arrested on a Sex Charge Said to Be Assistant Principal
item.description: Federal prosecutors says Bond Ng used his apartment in Long Island City to arrange for a woman to have sex with clients.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.description: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Some analysts say the tariffs ruled illegal by the Supreme Court last week had raised as much as $175 billion.

item.title: Trump Says General Caine Sees Easy Victory if U.S. Attacks Iran
item.description: The remarks differ from what Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is said to have told the president in high-level White House meetings.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in December. President Trump has been leaning toward conducting an initial strike against Iran in coming days intended to demonstrate to the country’s leaders that they must be willing to agree to give up the ability to make a nuclear weapon.

item.title: The Newest Player in A.I.’s Supply Chain Is a Toilet Maker
item.description: A British investor urged the Japanese company Toto to produce its advanced ceramics not for toilet seats and bidets, but for A.I. semiconductors.

item.title: Transit in the New York Region Is Recovering Slowly After Storm
item.description: Some service in and around New York City may remain suspended on Tuesday, and most trains and buses that are running will be subject to delays or limited schedules.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

media:content.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Moynihan Train Hall in Manhattan’s Penn Station on Monday.

item.title: After Chaos Rips Across Mexico, the Remnants of Cartel Violence Haunt Residents
item.description: Charred vehicles cluttered deserted streets as residents started to emerge from their homes in Guadalajara, which was hit hard by violence after the death of a cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez

media:content.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Empty streets and closed businesses on Monday in downtown Guadalajara.

item.title: What the Snowstorm Looked Like Across the Northeast
item.description: Record-breaking amounts of snow fell in many parts of the region, blanketing the area with snow in the second large storm of the year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Judson Jones

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times

item.title: Even in a Blizzard, Food Delivery in New York City Continues
item.description: On Monday, Mayor Zohran Mamdani banned nearly all traffic from the streets. Among the exceptions were emergency vehicles and electric delivery bikes.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag

media:content.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: One of New York City’s 80,000 food delivery workers, or deliveristas, braves the blizzard.

item.title: Pentagon Pulls Support for Air Safety Bill Written After D.C. Helicopter and Plane Crash
item.description: The legislation, which the House is expected to vote on Tuesday, would require military and commercial aircraft to use certain tracking technology to avoid collisions.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The bill would force a safety review of flight routes at all large and midsize airports, including Ronald Reagan National Airport in Arlington, Va.

item.title: Texas Rep. Tony Gonzales Pressured to Resign Over Sexual Messages to Staff Member
item.description: Democrats and Republicans urged Tony Gonzales to step down after allegations that he had sent inappropriate texts to a staff member and had a sexual relationship with her.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Tony Gonzales of Texas, who is facing a tough re-election fight, has denied engaging in a sexual relationship with a staff member.

item.title: The Workers Who Couldn’t Stay Home
item.description: Despite the snowstorm battering the New York area, workers whose jobs require them to show up in person found ways to attend to their duties.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman, Nate Schweber, Miles G. Cohen, Cassidy Jensen and Mark Bonamo

media:content.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Snow or no snow, many New Yorkers had to report to work.

item.title: Snowstorm Is ‘as Bad as I’ve Seen It,’ Massachusetts Governor Says
item.description: Gov. Maura Healey said there were nearly 300,000 power outages throughout the state and about 350 cars stuck on roadways, some with drivers still in them.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Jenna Russell

media:content.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Wind gusts topping 60 miles per hour and snowfall exceeding two feet in some counties hindered the effort to restore power in the state on Monday.

item.title: New York Democrats Have a Chance to Vote Against the A.I. Oligarchs
item.description: There’s a huge political opportunity for the party that can stand up for human beings in the face of A.I.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

media:content.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: Blizzard Slams Northeast with Heavy Snow, Disrupting Travel
item.description: Several cities across the Northeast received at least two feet of snow, bringing many places to a standstill.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brooklyn on Monday morning. New York City was expected to get the heaviest snow of the storm on Monday.

item.title: La CIA le dio a México información ‘decisiva’ para localizar al ‘Mencho’
item.description: Las autoridades mexicanas dijeron que habían encontrado al escurridizo capo de la droga siguiendo a una pareja sentimental. La CIA proporcionó algunos datos de inteligencia fundamentales para la operación.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Fuerzas especiales mexicanas en Ciudad de México el domingo. La inteligencia de la CIA ayudó a conducir a las fuerzas especiales hasta el líder del cártel.

item.title: Five Big Political Questions About Trump’s State of the Union Speech
item.description: Tariffs, the cost of living, immigration: The president has a careful line to walk on major issues.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Ilia Malinin Performed His Final Winter Olympics Skate in Balmain Jeans
item.description: For his final skate at the Winter Olympics in Italy, Ilia Malinin traded a spangly body suit for a hoodie and (designer) jeans.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi

media:content.media:credit: Ashley Landis/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Ilia Malinin wore Balmain jeans with a hoodie sold by the rapper NF for his performance at the Winter Olympics figure skating exhibition gala on Saturday.

item.title: Hunkering Down in Mexico, Some Hope for a Flight Out Amid Burning Cars
item.description: People from Canada and the United States tell of scrambling for safety, food and flights after violence erupted in Mexico when a cartel boss died in custody.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

media:content.media:credit: Reuters
media:content.media:description: Tourists watching a smoke rising after cartel members blocked roads and burned down businesses after a military operation led to the death of the Mexican drug lord Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

item.title: Violence in Mexico After Cartel Boss Is Killed
item.description: Mexican officials carried out an operation that killed the nation’s most wanted cartel boss Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, known as “El Mencho.” The death of Mr. Oseguera, who was the head of Mexico’s most powerful criminal organization, set off a wave of violence across the country.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus blocking a roadway in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Mexico Is on Edge After the Killing of a Cartel Boss
item.description: Also, a blizzard sweeps through the Northeast. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara today.

item.title: Is A.I. Changing the Way You Teach Writing? Tell Us.
item.description: We want to hear from high school teachers and college professors who assign writing.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Generative A.I. is making many teachers and professors rethink what types of writing they assign and where writing is produced.

item.title: Canada to Probe What OpenAI Knew About Tumbler Ridge Shooter
item.description: The company suspended the killer’s ChatGPT account over a policy violation in June, eight months before the attacks in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial for the victims of a the mass shooting this month at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia.

item.title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Supreme Court, Winter Olympics, Lunar New Year
item.description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.description: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Gen. Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, Mexico’s defense minister, described this weekend’s operation against a top cartel leader at a news conference in Mexico City on Monday with President Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: Nick Reiner se declara no culpable de los asesinatos de Rob y Michele Reiner, sus padres
item.description: Reiner, que tiene la cabeza rapada y vestía un uniforme marrón de presidiario, dijo ‘Sí’ con voz clara cuando el juez le preguntó si renunciaba a su derecho a un juicio rápido.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Matt Stevens

media:content.media:credit: Foto de consorcio por Chris Torres
media:content.media:description: Nick Reiner renunció el lunes a su derecho a un juicio rápido, dos meses después de ser acusado de asesinato en primer grado.

item.title: New York City Restaurants Face the Blizzard
item.description: Across New York City, restaurateurs and cafe owners weigh logistics and the safety of staff against the demands of customers and a slow winter.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

media:content.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: After many of its staff decided they wanted to work, the bakery Welcome Home in Bedford-Stuyvesant decided to open for businesses on Monday and sold out within hours.

item.title: La violencia en México tras la muerte del ‘Mencho’ en videos
item.description: Grupos armados bloquearon calles e incendiaron supermercados y bancos después de que el gobierno mexicano anunciara la muerte del líder más buscado del narcotráfico en México.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum and Pablo Robles

item.title: C.I.A. Intelligence Helped Lead Mexican Authorities to ‘El Mencho’
item.description: Mexican officials said they had found the elusive cartel kingpin by tracking a romantic partner. The C.I.A. provided some intelligence critical to the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mexican special forces in Mexico City on Sunday. C.I.A. intelligence helped lead the special forces to the cartel leader.

item.title: New York City’s Homeless Population Faces Another Dangerous Storm
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said on Monday that his administration had taken lessons from the city’s last storm, when at least 20 people died after exposure to the cold.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Parnell and Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A homeless encampment in Queens. Mayor Zohran Mamdani said on Monday that so far, no outdoor deaths had been reported in New York City during the blizzard.

item.title: Anthropic Accuses 3 Chinese Companies of Harvesting Its Data
item.description: The San Francisco start-up claimed that DeepSeek, Moonshot and MiniMax used approximately 24,000 fraudulent accounts to train their own chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

media:content.media:credit: Cfoto/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: DeepSeek is among the three Chinese start-ups accused of using data from Anthropic’s A.I. system to train their own, a process called distillation.

item.title: Record Snowfall Slams New England and Leaves New York City Snarled
item.description: Three feet of snow fell in parts of Rhode Island. It’s not clear if many train and bus lines around the New York region will run on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
